    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • a) Registering Datasets
        • Dataset.Tabular

      • b) Reading Datasets into Memory
        • Dataset.Tabular
        • Dataset.Sequence
        • Dataset.Image
    • 2. Selecting Features and Labels.
      • a) Select the Label column(s).
        • ORM
        • Deriving Labels
        • Reading Labels
      • b) Select the Feature column(s).
        • ORM
        • Specifying Features
        • Reading Features
    • 3. Slicing samples.
      • a) Define sliding time series Windows.
        • ORM
        • Specifying Windows
        • Reading Windows
      • b) Slice samples with a Splitset.
        • Stratification
        • Splitting Strategies
        • Reading Splitsets
      • c) Create a Foldset for cross-validation.
        • ORM
        • Fold objects
        • Specifying Foldsets
        • Reading Foldsets
    • 4. Preprocessing - Interpolation.
      • ORM
      • a) Interpolate Labels with LabelInterpolater.
      • b) Interpolate Features with Interpolaterset.
    • 5. Preprocessing - Encoding.
      • Encoding
      • a) Encode labels with LabelCoder.
        • Creating a LabelCoder
      • b) Encode Features sequentially with Ensoderset.
        • Filtering feature columns
    • 6. Preprocessing - Reshaping.
      • ORM
      • Reshaping by Index
      • Reshaping Explicitly
      • Multiplicative Reshaping
    • 7. Defining Architectures & Hyperparameters.
      • a) Define an Algorithm
        • Model Definition
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
      • b) Combinations of hyperparameters with Hyperparamset.
        • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 8. Queue of training Jobs.
      • a) Job objects.
      • b) Executing Jobs.
        • i) queue.run_jobs()
        • ii) DEPRECATED - queue.run_jobs(in_background=True).
      • c) Predictors are the trained models.
        • Fetching the trained model.
        • Fetching the hyperparameters.
      • d) Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
        • Fetching metrics.
    • 9. Metrics & Visualization

PyTorch: Image Classify BinaryÔÉÅ

Brain Tumor Detection via Binary Classification of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Scans

[1]:

cd '~/Desktop/AIQC'

/Users/layne/Desktop/AIQC

[2]:

import aiqc
from aiqc import datum

PipelineÔÉÅ

This dataset is comprised of:

  • Features = folder of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of brain samples.

  • Labels = tabular data denoting the presence of a tumor.

[3]:

from sklearn.preprocessing import FunctionTransformer
from aiqc.utils import div255, mult255

[4]:

img_splitset = aiqc.Pipeline.Image(
    # --- Label preprocessing ---
    label_df_or_path = datum.to_pandas('brain_tumor.csv')
    , label_dtype = None
    , label_column = 'status'
    , label_interpolater = None
    , label_encoder = None

    # --- Feature preprocessing ---
    , feature_folder_or_urls = datum.get_remote_urls(manifest_name='brain_tumor.csv')
    , feature_dtype = 'float64'
    , feature_interpolaters = None
    , feature_window = None
    , feature_encoders = dict(#pixel values are 0-255 so we will standardize by dividing by 255.
        sklearn_preprocess= FunctionTransformer(div255, inverse_func=mult255)
        , dtypes = 'float64'
    )
    , feature_reshape_indices = (0,2,3)#reshape for Conv1D grayscale.

    # --- Stratification ---
    , size_test = 0.22
    , size_validation = 0.14
    , fold_count = None
    , bin_count = None
)

ModelingÔÉÅ

[10]:

import torch
import torch.nn as nn

[11]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    model = nn.Sequential(
        #Conv1d(in_channels, out_channels, kernel_size, stride=1, padding=0, dilation=1, groups=1, bias=True, padding_mode='zeros')
        nn.Conv1d(
            in_channels=160 #running with `in_channels` as the width of the image. which is index[1]
            , out_channels=56 #arbitrary number. treating this as network complexity.
            , kernel_size=3
            , padding=1
        )
        , nn.ReLU() #wasnt learning with tanh
        , nn.MaxPool1d(kernel_size=2, stride=2)
        , nn.Dropout(p=0.4)

        , nn.Conv1d(
            in_channels=56, out_channels=128,
            kernel_size=3, padding=1
        )
        , nn.ReLU() #wasnt learning with tanh
        , nn.MaxPool1d(kernel_size=2, stride=2)
        , nn.Dropout(p=0.4)

        , nn.Flatten()# output [5x1440]
        , nn.Linear(3840,3840)
        , nn.BatchNorm1d(3840,3840)
        , nn.ReLU()
        , nn.Dropout(p=0.4)

        , nn.Linear(3840, 1)
        , nn.Sigmoid()
    )
    return model

[12]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    ## --- Prepare mini batches for analysis ---
    batched_features, batched_labels = aiqc.utils.torch_batcher(
        samples_train['features'], samples_train['labels'],
        batch_size=5, enforce_sameSize=False, allow_1Sample=False
    )

    ## --- Metrics ---
    acc = torchmetrics.Accuracy()
    # Modeled after `keras.model.History.history` object.
    history = dict(
        loss=list(), accuracy=list(),
        val_loss=list(), val_accuracy=list()
    )

    ## --- Training loop ---
    epochs = 40
    print(f" Epoch | Train_Loss | Eval_Loss | Train_Acc | Eval_Acc ")
    print("-------+------------+-----------+-----------+----------")
    for epoch in range(epochs):
        # --- Batch training ---
        for i, batch in enumerate(batched_features):
            # Make raw (unlabeled) predictions.
            batch_probability = model(batched_features[i])
            batch_loss = loser(batch_probability, batched_labels[i])
            # Backpropagation.
            optimizer.zero_grad()
            batch_loss.backward()
            optimizer.step()

        ## --- Epoch metrics ---
        # Overall performance on training data.
        train_probability = model(samples_train['features'])
        train_loss = loser(train_probability, samples_train['labels'])
        train_acc = acc(train_probability, samples_train['labels'].to(torch.short))
        history['loss'].append(float(train_loss))
        history['accuracy'].append(float(train_acc))
        # Performance on evaluation data.
        eval_probability = model(samples_evaluate['features'])
        eval_loss = loser(eval_probability, samples_evaluate['labels'])
        eval_acc = acc(eval_probability, samples_evaluate['labels'].to(torch.short))
        history['val_loss'].append(float(eval_loss))
        history['val_accuracy'].append(float(eval_acc))
        # Metric readout.
        print(f" {epoch}   | {train_loss}       | {eval_loss}      | {train_acc}      | {eval_acc}")

[13]:

# hyperparameters = dict(
#     concave         = [False]
#     , conv_blocks   = [4]
#     , conv_neurons  = [24]
#     , pool_size     = [2]
#     , kernel_size   = [3]
#     , batch_size    = [8] #8 did best. tried 5 and 6 again, no.
#     , cnn_init      = ['normal'] #default is glorot
#     , dense_blocks  = [1]
#     , dense_neurons = [32] #64 did well.
#     , epoch_count   = [500]
# )

[15]:

queue = aiqc.Experiment(
    # --- Analysis type ---
    library = "pytorch"
    , analysis_type = "classification_binary"

    # --- Model functions ---
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train
    , fn_lose = None #auto
    , fn_optimize = None #auto
    , fn_predict = None #auto

    # --- Training options ---
    , repeat_count = 2
    , hyperparameters = None
    , search_percent = None

    # --- Data source ---
    , splitset_id = img_splitset.id
    , foldset_id = None
    , hide_test = False
)

[16]:

queue.run_jobs()
